statement.text: Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is the gold standard for evaluating iliofemoral venous obstruction, providing real-time cross-sectional imaging that quantifies stenosis severity, identifies wall abnormalities, and guides stent sizing and placement with superior accuracy compared to venography.
statement.formal: IVUS_Venous: Cross-Sectional_Area_Measurement → Stenosis_Quantification > Venography (30-50% more accurate)

explanation.intuition: IVUS is like putting a tiny ultrasound camera inside the vein to look at the walls from the inside. While venography shows a silhouette (like a shadow on a wall), IVUS shows the actual structure of the vein wall and any compression, webs, or damage.
explanation.key_insight: Venography consistently underestimates iliac vein stenosis by 30-50% because external compression flattens the vein without narrowing its length. IVUS directly measures cross-sectional area, which is the true determinant of hemodynamic significance. A stenosis appearing as 50% on venography may be 80% by area on IVUS.
explanation.technical_details: IVUS catheters (8-10 French) use either mechanical rotating transducers (20-40 MHz) or phased array technology to generate 360-degree cross-sectional images. The catheter is advanced beyond the area of interest and slowly withdrawn during imaging. Key measurements include cross-sectional area (CSA), minimum and maximum diameters, and comparison to normal reference segments. Findings include external compression, intimal hyperplasia, webs, synechiae, and chronic thrombus.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Venography is sufficient for treatment planning. Reality: IVUS changes treatment decisions in 20-40% of cases by revealing stenosis severity missed on venography.
Misconception: IVUS is only for complex cases. Reality: IVUS should be routine for any iliofemoral intervention given its superior accuracy.
Misconception: Area stenosis correlates linearly with hemodynamic impact. Reality: >50% area stenosis is the threshold for hemodynamic significance.

key_measurements.maximum_diameter: Largest dimension (may be normal if compressed)
key_measurements.reference_area: Normal segment for comparison and stent sizing

may_thurner: External compression of left common iliac vein
Spur or web at compression point

treatment_guidance: Size stents to reference segment diameter
quality_control: Identify residual stenosis requiring further dilation

diagnosis: Insert IVUS catheter via access sheath
Measure areas at stenosis and reference segments
treatment: Use IVUS for all iliofemoral interventions

definition.@value: The application of intravascular ultrasound imaging to evaluate iliofemoral venous obstruction, providing cross-sectional visualization of vein walls, accurate stenosis quantification, and real-time guidance for stent sizing and placement.

learning_objectives: Explain the principles of IVUS imaging in veins
Interpret IVUS findings in May-Thurner and post-thrombotic disease
Apply IVUS measurements for stent sizing
Describe the advantages of IVUS over venography
clinical_pearls: IVUS changes treatment decisions in 20-40% of cases
>50% cross-sectional area stenosis is hemodynamically significant
Size stents to the reference segment, not the stenotic area
Always confirm stent apposition with post-deployment IVUS
